issues.description: The UML diagram defines the Ride attribute as “shortCode” (char) and thus students expect a getter getShortCode(), but the solution code names the field “abbreviation” with getter getAbbreviation(). This naming mismatch between the problem statement and the implementation can confuse students when they write their code and when automated tests look for getShortCode().
issues.suggested_fix: Align the UML and implementation: either rename the attribute in the UML to “abbreviation” (and update the problem text) or rename the field and its getter in the code to “shortCode”/getShortCode() so both artifacts match.

issues.description: The UML diagram and problem statement specify the Ride class has an attribute named 'shortCode', but the reference implementation names the same field and its constructor parameter 'abbreviation'. This mismatch hinders mapping the UML-provided attribute to the code.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the field, getter, and constructor parameter in the code from 'abbreviation' to 'shortCode' (and adjust the getter to getShortCode()) so it matches the UML specification.
